iti84:0.4.eng: For the Welfare of the People

iti84:1.1.eng: This was said by the Buddha, the Perfected One: that is what I heard.

iti84:2.1.pli: “Tayome puggalā loke uppajjamānā uppajjanti bahujanahitāya bahujanasukhāya lokānukampāya atthāya hitāya sukhāya devamanussānaṃ.
iti84:2.1.eng: “These three individuals, mendicants, arise in the world for the welfare and happiness of the people, out of sympathy for the world, for the benefit, welfare, and happiness of gods and humans.

iti84:2.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, tathāgato loke uppajjati arahaṃ sammāsambuddho vijjācaraṇasampanno sugato lokavidū anuttaro purisadammasārathi satthā devamanussānaṃ buddho bhagavā.
iti84:2.3.eng: It’s when a Realized One arises in the world, perfected, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme guide for those fit for training, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed.

iti84:2.4.pli: So dhammaṃ deseti ādikalyāṇaṃ majjhekalyāṇaṃ pariyosānakalyāṇaṃ sātthaṃ sabyañjanaṃ, kevalaparipuṇṇaṃ parisuddhaṃ brahmacariyaṃ pakāseti.
iti84:2.4.eng: He proclaims a teaching that is good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased. And he reveals a spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure.

iti84:2.5.pli: Ayaṃ, bhikkhave, paṭhamo puggalo loke uppajjamāno uppajjati bahujanahitāya bahujanasukhāya lokānukampāya atthāya hitāya sukhāya devamanussānaṃ.
iti84:2.5.eng: This is the first individual who arises in the world for the welfare and happiness of the people, out of sympathy for the world, for the benefit, welfare, and happiness of gods and humans.

iti84:3.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, tasseva satthu sāvako arahaṃ hoti khīṇāsavo vusitavā katakaraṇīyo ohitabhāro anuppattasadattho parikkhīṇabhavasaṃyojano sammadaññāvimutto.
iti84:3.1.eng: Furthermore, it’s when a mendicant is a perfected one, with defilements ended, who has completed the spiritual journey, done what had to be done, laid down the burden, achieved their heart’s goal, utterly ended the fetter of continued existence, and is rightly freed through enlightenment.

iti84:3.2.pli: So dhammaṃ deseti ādikalyāṇaṃ majjhekalyāṇaṃ pariyosānakalyāṇaṃ sātthaṃ sabyañjanaṃ, kevalaparipuṇṇaṃ parisuddhaṃ brahmacariyaṃ pakāseti.
iti84:3.2.eng: They teach Dhamma that’s good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased. And they reveal a spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure.

iti84:3.3.pli: Ayaṃ, bhikkhave, dutiyo puggalo loke uppajjamāno uppajjati bahujanahitāya bahujanasukhāya lokānukampāya atthāya hitāya sukhāya devamanussānaṃ.
iti84:3.3.eng: This is the second individual who arises in the world for the welfare and happiness of the people, out of sympathy for the world, for the benefit, welfare, and happiness of gods and humans.

iti84:4.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, tasseva satthu sāvako sekho hoti pāṭipado bahussuto sīlavatūpapanno.
iti84:4.1.eng: Furthermore, it’s when a disciple of that Teacher is a trainee, a learned practitioner with precepts and observances intact.

iti84:4.2.pli: Sopi dhammaṃ deseti ādikalyāṇaṃ majjhekalyāṇaṃ pariyosānakalyāṇaṃ sātthaṃ sabyañjanaṃ, kevalaparipuṇṇaṃ parisuddhaṃ brahmacariyaṃ pakāseti.
iti84:4.2.eng: They teach Dhamma that’s good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased. And they reveal a spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure.

iti84:4.3.pli: Ayaṃ, bhikkhave, tatiyo puggalo loke uppajjamāno uppajjati bahujanahitāya bahujanasukhāya lokānukampāya atthāya hitāya sukhāya devamanussānaṃ.
iti84:4.3.eng: This is the third individual who arises in the world for the welfare and happiness of the people, out of sympathy for the world, for the benefit, welfare, and happiness of gods and humans.

iti84:4.4.pli: Ime kho, bhikkhave, tayo puggalā loke uppajjamānā uppajjanti bahujanahitāya bahujanasukhāya lokānukampāya atthāya hitāya sukhāya devamanussānan”ti.
iti84:4.4.eng: These are the three individuals who arise in the world for the welfare and happiness of the people, out of sympathy for the world, for the benefit, welfare, and happiness of gods and humans.”

iti84:5.1.eng: “The Teacher is the first, the great seer,

iti84:5.2.eng: following whom is the evolved disciple,

iti84:5.3.eng: and then a trainee, a practitioner,

iti84:5.4.eng: learned, with precepts and observances intact.

iti84:6.1.eng: These three are first among gods and humans,

iti84:6.3.eng: They fling open the door to freedom from death,

iti84:7.1.eng: Following the path so well taught

iti84:7.3.eng: those who are diligent in the Holy One’s teaching

iti84:7.4.eng: make an end of suffering in this very life.”

iti84:8.1.pli: Ayampi attho vutto bhagavatā, iti me sutanti.
iti84:8.1.eng: This too is a matter that was spoken by the Blessed One: that is what I heard.

iti85:1.1.eng: This was said by the Buddha, the Perfected One: that is what I heard.

iti85:2.1.eng: “Mendicants, meditate observing the ugliness of the body.

iti85:2.2.pli: ānāpānassati ca vo ajjhattaṃ parimukhaṃ sūpaṭṭhitā hotu;
iti85:2.2.eng: Let mindfulness of breathing be well-established internally in your presence.

iti85:2.3.eng: Meditate observing the impermanence of all conditions.

iti85:2.4.pli: Asubhānupassīnaṃ, bhikkhave, kāyasmiṃ viharataṃ yo subhāya dhātuyā rāgānusayo so pahīyati.
iti85:2.4.eng: As you meditate observing the ugliness of the body, you will give up desire for the body.

iti85:2.5.pli: Ānāpānassatiyā ajjhattaṃ parimukhaṃ sūpaṭṭhititāya ye bāhirā vitakkāsayā vighātapakkhikā, te na honti.
iti85:2.5.eng: When mindfulness of breathing is well-established internally in your presence, there will be no distressing external thoughts or wishes.

iti85:2.6.pli: Sabbasaṅkhāresu aniccānupassīnaṃ viharataṃ yā avijjā sā pahīyati, yā vijjā sā uppajjatī”ti.
iti85:2.6.eng: When you meditate observing the impermanence of all conditions, ignorance is given up and knowledge arises.”

iti85:5.1.pli: Ayampi attho vutto bhagavatā, iti me sutanti.
iti85:5.1.eng: This too is a matter that was spoken by the Blessed One: that is what I heard.

iti86:0.4.eng: Practicing In Line With the Teaching

iti86:1.1.eng: This was said by the Buddha, the Perfected One: that is what I heard.

iti86:2.1.eng: “Regarding a mendicant practicing in line with the teaching, it is in line with the teaching to declare that
iti86:2.1.comm: This phrase, commonly used in the Suttas, has a precedent in Rig Veda 3.17.1, where the sacred fire is kindled according to the precedent ordained by the first sacrificer.

iti86:2.2.pli: dhammānudhammapaṭipannoyanti bhāsamāno dhammaññeva bhāsati no adhammaṃ, vitakkayamāno vā dhammavitakkaññeva vitakketi no adhammavitakkaṃ, tadubhayaṃ vā pana abhinivejjetvā upekkhako viharati sato sampajāno”ti.
iti86:2.2.eng: this is what it means to practice in line with the teaching. When speaking, they speak on the teaching, not against it. When thinking, they think on the teaching, not against it. And rejecting both, they meditate staying equanimous, mindful and aware.”

iti86:3.1.eng: “Delighting in the teaching, enjoying the teaching,

iti86:3.3.eng: a mendicant who recollects the teaching

iti86:3.4.eng: doesn’t fall away from the true teaching.

iti86:5.1.pli: Ayampi attho vutto bhagavatā, iti me sutanti.
iti86:5.1.eng: This too is a matter that was spoken by the Blessed One: that is what I heard.

iti87:1.1.eng: This was said by the Buddha, the Perfected One: that is what I heard.

iti87:2.1.pli: “Tayome, bhikkhave, akusalavitakkā andhakaraṇā acakkhukaraṇā aññāṇakaraṇā paññānirodhikā vighātapakkhikā anibbānasaṃvattanikā.
iti87:2.1.eng: “Mendicants, these three unskillful thoughts are destroyers of sight, vision, and knowledge. They block wisdom, they’re on the side of distress, and they don’t lead to extinguishment.

iti87:2.3.pli: Kāmavitakko, bhikkhave, andhakaraṇo acakkhukaraṇo aññāṇakaraṇo paññānirodhiko vighātapakkhiko anibbānasaṃvattaniko.

iti87:2.4.pli: Byāpādavitakko, bhikkhave, andhakaraṇo acakkhukaraṇo aññāṇakaraṇo paññānirodhiko vighātapakkhiko anibbānasaṃvattaniko.

iti87:2.5.pli: Vihiṃsāvitakko, bhikkhave, andhakaraṇo acakkhukaraṇo aññāṇakaraṇo paññānirodhiko vighātapakkhiko anibbānasaṃvattaniko.

iti87:2.6.pli: Ime kho, bhikkhave, tayo akusalavitakkā andhakaraṇā acakkhukaraṇā aññāṇakaraṇā paññānirodhikā vighātapakkhikā anibbānasaṃvattanikā.
iti87:2.6.eng: These are the three unskillful thoughts that are destroyers of sight, vision, and knowledge. They block wisdom, they’re on the side of distress, and they don’t lead to extinguishment.

iti87:3.1.pli: Tayome, bhikkhave, kusalavitakkā anandhakaraṇā cakkhukaraṇā ñāṇakaraṇā paññāvuddhikā avighātapakkhikā nibbānasaṃvattanikā.
iti87:3.1.eng: These three skillful thoughts are creators of sight, vision, and knowledge. They grow wisdom, they’re on the side of solace, and they lead to extinguishment.

iti87:3.3.pli: Nekkhammavitakko, bhikkhave, anandhakaraṇo cakkhukaraṇo ñāṇakaraṇo paññāvuddhiko avighātapakkhiko nibbānasaṃvattaniko.

iti87:3.4.pli: Abyāpādavitakko, bhikkhave, anandhakaraṇo cakkhukaraṇo ñāṇakaraṇo paññāvuddhiko avighātapakkhiko nibbānasaṃvattaniko.

iti87:3.5.pli: Avihiṃsāvitakko, bhikkhave, anandhakaraṇo cakkhukaraṇo ñāṇakaraṇo paññāvuddhiko avighātapakkhiko nibbānasaṃvattaniko.

iti87:3.6.pli: Ime kho, bhikkhave, tayo kusalavitakkā anandhakaraṇā cakkhukaraṇā ñāṇakaraṇā paññāvuddhikā avighātapakkhikā nibbānasaṃvattanikā”ti.
iti87:3.6.eng: These are the three skillful thoughts that are creators of sight, vision, and knowledge. They grow wisdom, they’re on the side of solace, and they lead to extinguishment.”

iti88:2.1.pli: “Tayome, bhikkhave, antarāmalā antarāamittā antarāsapattā antarāvadhakā antarāpaccatthikā.
iti88:2.1.eng: “Mendicants, there are these three inner stains, inner foes, inner enemies, inner killers, and inner adversaries.

iti88:2.3.pli: Lobho, bhikkhave, antarāmalo antarāamitto antarāsapatto antarāvadhako antarāpaccatthiko.

iti88:2.4.pli: Doso, bhikkhave, antarāmalo antarāamitto antarāsapatto antarāvadhako antarāpaccatthiko.

iti88:2.5.pli: Moho, bhikkhave, antarāmalo antarāamitto antarāsapatto antarāvadhako antarāpaccatthiko.

iti88:2.6.pli: Ime kho, bhikkhave, tayo antarāmalā antarāamittā antarāsapattā antarāvadhakā antarāpaccatthikā”ti.
iti88:2.6.eng: These three are inner stains, inner foes, inner enemies, inner killers, and inner adversaries.”

iti89:2.1.pli: “Tīhi, bhikkhave, asaddhammehi abhibhūto pariyādinnacitto devadatto āpāyiko nerayiko kappaṭṭho atekiccho.
iti89:2.1.eng: “Mendicants, overcome and overwhelmed by three things that oppose the true teaching, Devadatta is going to a place of loss, to hell, there to remain for an eon, irredeemable.

iti89:2.3.pli: Pāpicchatāya, bhikkhave, abhibhūto pariyādinnacitto devadatto āpāyiko nerayiko kappaṭṭho atekiccho.

iti89:2.4.pli: Pāpamittatāya, bhikkhave, abhibhūto pariyādinnacitto devadatto āpāyiko nerayiko kappaṭṭho atekiccho.

iti89:2.5.pli: Sati kho pana uttarikaraṇīye oramattakena visesādhigamena antarā vosānaṃ āpādi.
iti89:2.5.eng: When there is still more to be done, stopping half-way after achieving some trifling distinction.

iti89:2.6.pli: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, tīhi asaddhammehi abhibhūto pariyādinnacitto devadatto āpāyiko nerayiko kappaṭṭho atekiccho”ti.
iti89:2.6.eng: Overcome and overwhelmed by these three things that oppose the true teaching, Devadatta is going to a place of loss, to hell, there to remain for an eon, irredeemable.”

iti89:5.3.eng: He has fallen to Avīci hell,
iti89:5.3.comm: Despite its fame, this, together with its parallel at Kd 17:4.8.11, is the only mention of Avīci hell in early Buddhism. It became a standard hell in later texts of the Buddhists (eg. Kv 23.3:1.10, Vb 3:23.4, Cnd 23:44.3) and Brahmans (eg. Bhāgavata Purāṇa 5.26.28). The commentary explains avīci as “without interval”, i.e. “unrelenting”; a similar explanation is cited by Vasubandhu at Abhidharmakośabhāṣya 3.58.

iti89:5.4.comm: Compare the description of hell as “four-doored” at MN 129:16.3 = MN 130:16.3 = AN 3.36:16.1.

iti9:2.1.pli: “Lobhaṃ, bhikkhave, anabhijānaṃ aparijānaṃ tattha cittaṃ avirājayaṃ appajahaṃ abhabbo dukkhakkhayāya.
iti9:2.1.eng: “Mendicants, without directly knowing and completely understanding greed, without dispassion for it and giving it up, you can’t end suffering.

iti9:2.2.pli: Lobhañca kho, bhikkhave, abhijānaṃ parijānaṃ tattha cittaṃ virājayaṃ pajahaṃ bhabbo dukkhakkhayāyā”ti.
iti9:2.2.eng: By directly knowing and completely understanding greed, having dispassion for it and giving it up, you can end suffering.”

iti90:1.1.eng: This was said by the Buddha, the Perfected One: that is what I heard.

iti90:2.1.eng: “Mendicants, these three kinds of confidence are the best.

iti90:2.3.pli: Yāvatā, bhikkhave, sattā apadā vā dvipadā vā catuppadā vā bahuppadā vā rūpino vā arūpino vā saññino vā asaññino vā nevasaññināsaññino vā, tathāgato tesaṃ aggamakkhāyati arahaṃ sammāsambuddho.
iti90:2.3.eng: Mendicants, the Realized One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha, is said to be the best of all sentient beings—be they footless, with two feet, four feet, or many feet; with form or formless; with perception or without perception or with neither perception nor non-perception.

iti90:2.4.pli: Ye, bhikkhave, buddhe pasannā, agge te pasannā.
iti90:2.4.eng: Those who have confidence in the Buddha have confidence in the best.

iti90:2.5.pli: Agge kho pana pasannānaṃ aggo vipāko hoti.
iti90:2.5.eng: Having confidence in the best, the result is the best.

iti90:3.1.pli: Yāvatā, bhikkhave, dhammā saṅkhatā vā asaṅkhatā vā, virāgo tesaṃ aggamakkhāyati, yadidaṃ madanimmadano pipāsavinayo ālayasamugghāto vaṭṭupacchedo taṇhakkhayo virāgo nirodho nibbānaṃ.
iti90:3.1.eng: Fading away is said to be the best of all things whether conditioned or unconditioned. That is, the quelling of vanity, the removing of thirst, the abolishing of clinging, the breaking of the round, the ending of craving, fading away, cessation, extinguishment.

iti90:3.2.pli: Ye, bhikkhave, virāge dhamme pasannā, agge te pasannā.
iti90:3.2.eng: Those who have confidence in the teaching of fading away have confidence in the best.

iti90:3.3.pli: Agge kho pana pasannānaṃ aggo vipāko hoti.
iti90:3.3.eng: Having confidence in the best, the result is the best.

iti90:4.1.pli: Yāvatā, bhikkhave, saṅghā vā gaṇā vā, tathāgatasāvakasaṅgho tesaṃ aggamakkhāyati, yadidaṃ cattāri purisayugāni aṭṭha purisapuggalā esa bhagavato sāvakasaṅgho āhuneyyo pāhuneyyo dakkhiṇeyyo añjalikaraṇīyo anuttaraṃ puññakkhettaṃ lokassa.
iti90:4.1.eng: The Saṅgha of the Realized One’s disciples is said to be the best of all communities and groups. It consists of the four pairs, the eight individual persons. This is the Saṅgha of the Buddha’s disciples that is worthy of offerings dedicated to the gods, worthy of hospitality, worthy of a religious donation, worthy of greeting with joined palms, and is the supreme field of merit for the world.

iti90:4.2.pli: Ye, bhikkhave, saṅghe pasannā, agge te pasannā.
iti90:4.2.eng: Those who have confidence in the Saṅgha have confidence in the best.

iti90:4.3.pli: Agge kho pana pasannānaṃ aggo vipāko hoti.
iti90:4.3.eng: Having confidence in the best, the result is the best.

iti90:4.4.eng: These are the three best kinds of confidence.”

iti90:5.1.eng: “For those who, knowing the best teaching,

iti90:5.2.eng: base their confidence on the best—

iti90:5.3.eng: confident in the best Awakened One,

iti90:5.4.eng: supremely worthy of a religious donation;

iti90:6.2.eng: the bliss of fading and stilling;

iti90:8.1.eng: An intelligent person gives to the best,

iti90:8.3.eng: When they become a god or human,

iti90:8.4.eng: they rejoice at reaching the best.”

iti90:9.1.eng: This too is a matter that was spoken by the Blessed One: that is what I heard.
